title: Data preparation with the palaeoverse R package
text:
This unit of the workshop covers preparation and exploration of fossil occurrence data using the palaeoverse R package. The slides for the unit are available here and provide an introduction to palaeoverse and the available functionality. The code for the tutorial is available here and provides usage examples for helping you get started with the package.
This session is led by Lewis A. Jones. If you encounter any issues while working with these resources, please contact him here.

title: Food and drink
text:
UCL benefits very heavily from its central London location, and is only a short walk, bus, or tube away from areas such as Soho, Covent Garden, Islington, and Camden. For the closest lunch or dinner options within around five minutes of campus, we recommend the following:

Bloomsbury Farmers‚Äô Market (Thursday only) ‚Äì a big favourite with everybody in the office. Taking place in Torrington Square from around 12‚Äì2pm every Thursday, there are usually over 20 stalls selling a huge range of cuisines. Prices generally fall just under <¬£10.
Roti King ‚Äì very tasty Malaysian and Singaporean street food. You can‚Äôt book here, and queues often form outside if you want a table, but it‚Äôs worth it. You can pre-order and collect, or they will also deliver to UCL. Prices for main dishes range from ¬£5‚Äì10.
Noodle & Snack Èù¢ÈÅìÂùä - amazing handmade noodles and broths! The restaurant is small, and it can get very busy around lunch and dinner if you‚Äôre hoping to sit in, but they also do takeaway. A main and a side should cost ¬£10‚Äì20.
Franco Manca ‚Äì Good quality sourdough pizzas for <¬£10. Both eat in and takeaway options are available.
Rosa‚Äôs Thai ‚Äì A large selection of tasty Thai dishes with a sizeable number of vegetarian and vegan options. Lunch will likely cost ¬£10‚Äì20 per person. Eat in and takeaway options are available.
Mestizo ‚Äì delicious Mexican food with a large number of items on the menu. Expect a meal for one to cost around ¬£20.

title: Food and drink
text:
On Campus
UCL‚Äôs cafes all serve a similar selection of hot and cold drinks, sandwiches, salads, and microwaveable meals averaging around ¬£5‚Äì6. All of those listed here are within 3-4 minutes of the Kathleen Lonsdale Building, and are open from 8am onwards.
The main canteen (Wilkins Terrace and Lower Refectory) is open throughout the day, and offers a variety of cooked meals costing around ¬£5‚Äì7.

George Farha Caf√© (8am‚Äì6pm) ‚Äì the neighbour to the Kathleen Lonsdale Building
Print Room Caf√© (8am‚Äì8pm) ‚Äì perhaps the nicest setting if the sun‚Äôs out as there‚Äôs seating in a nice courtyard. As well as the usual sandwiches and salads, this caf√© also serves a few cooked options such as pasta dishes.
Gordon‚Äôs Caf√© (8am‚Äì7pm) ‚Äì Similar to George Farha, but with the bonus addition of pizza!
Wilkins Terrace and Lower Refectory (8‚Äì10:30am, 11:30am‚Äì7pm) ‚Äì located on the lower level of campus, the canteen houses 3 or 4 different outlets selling a variety of cooked dishes.

title: R for Palaeobiologists: Workshop and Hackathon
text:
7‚Äì8th September 2023, Kathleen Lonsdale Building, University College London

Welcome
This event is sponsored by the Palaeontological Association through a Grant-in-Aid (PA-GA202203) and the Paleontological Society through a small conference support grant.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
As with any community project, society, meeting, or event we feel it is important to established some expectations of behaviour.
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in this event a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
As with any community project, society, meeting, or event we feel it is important to established some expectations of behaviour.
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in this event a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Our Standards

Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our community include:

Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes, and learning from the experience
Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the overall community

Examples of unacceptable behavior include:

The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or advances of any kind
Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Public or private harassment
Publishing others‚Äô private information, such as a physical or email address, without their explicit permission
Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Enforcement Responsibilities

Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation decisions when appropriate.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Scope

This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Enforcement

Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement: Lewis A. Jones and Bethany Allen. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.
All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the reporter of any incident.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Enforcement Guidelines

Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:

1. Correction
Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.
Consequence: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.


2. Warning
Community Impact: A violation through a single incident or series of actions.
Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or permanent ban.


3. Temporary Ban
Community Impact: A serious violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior.
Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period. Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.


4. Permanent Ban
Community Impact: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment of an individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.
Consequence: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within the community.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
Attribution

This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant.
Community Impact Guidelines were inspired by Mozilla‚Äôs code of conduct enforcement ladder.

title: Getting here
text:
The event is hosted within the Kathleen Lonsdale Building at University College London.
The nearest major stations to the UCL campus are Euston and King‚Äôs Cross St.¬†Pancras. The Kathleen Lonsdale Building is a relatively short walk from both stations (7 and 15 minutes respectively). Alternatively, Buses 30, 73, and 205 run along Euston Road between the Kathleen Lonsdale Building and King‚Äôs Cross St Pancras.
The closest tube stations to UCL are:

Warren Street ‚Äì Victoria Line - Northern Line
Euston Square ‚Äì Circle Line - Hammersmith & City Line - Metropolitan Line
Russell Square ‚Äì Piccadilly Line

We highly recommend downloading the Citymapper app if you intend on travelling around London!

title: Getting here
text:
Finding the Workshop and Hackathon
The event will be held in the same room within the Kathleen Lonsdale Building. To enter the building, you can either use steps from Gower Pl, or by ramp through the eastern entrance via UCL‚Äôs main quad on Gower Street (see map for both). We will be working in Teaching Lab 1 (126) on the 1st floor of the Kathleen Lonsdale Building (signs will be in place upon arrival). Both stairs and an elevator can be accessed from the main lobby area near to the Deinonychus mount. Once on the first floor, take a left from the elevator or a right from the top of the stairs, before following the corridor all the way to its end!
Click here for an interactive map or see map below.

title: Accommodation
text:
For the cheapest accommodation options, we recommend reserving a room at one of several university halls which are hired out to visitors over the summer. A single room with shared bathroom facilities can be acquired from ¬£45 a night, with the cheapest ensuite options starting from ¬£65. You can use the following links to assess options:

University College London (UCL)
London School of Economics (LSE)
King‚Äôs College London (KCL)
Imperial College London (ICL)

Many major chain hotels can also be found within 10‚Äì15 minutes walking distance of UCL, with rates for a double ensuite starting from around ¬£100 a night. Some suggestions include:

Premier Inn London Euston
Premier Inn London St.¬†Pancras
Hub by Premier Inn Goodge Street

Multiple independent hotels also operate in the area, which can be viewed on booking.com.
We recommend booking as soon as possible to keep prices lower!

title: Entertainment
text:
Prince of Wales Feathers ‚Äì bustling pub with a roof terrace perfect for a summer‚Äôs eve!
Smuggler‚Äôs Tavern ‚Äì A cosy, nautical themed pub serving some very decent pizzas. On the second Friday of every month, the tavern has a karaoke night. We‚Äôre still unsure whether this is a good or bad thing. Probably both.
Carpenter‚Äôs Arms ‚Äì Cosy and slightly off the beaten track so doesn‚Äôt get busy too quickly.
Lore of the Land ‚Äì A very appealing wood panelled pub with a fancy restaurant upstairs. They win the award for the best smelling hand sanitizer.

title: Entertainment
section: Things to do in the immediate area
text:
Things to do in the immediate area

UCL‚Äôs Grant Museum of Zoology (1‚Äì5pm Tues to Fri) ‚Äì a five-minute walk from the workshop, this little museum hosts thousands of Zoological specimens in cabinets and jars. Highlights include the Micrarium and the (in)famous Jar of Moles.
Green Spaces ‚Äì Head just a few minutes away from Euston Road and you‚Äôll find a variety of green spaces perfect for a short stroll, reading a book, or a picnic. Close to UCL you can find Gordon Square, Tavistock Square Gardens, and Russell Square. For a larger space, we‚Äôd recommend the trip to Regent‚Äôs Park, home to London Zoo.
Wellcome Collection (10am‚Äì6pm) ‚Äì Located opposite the Kathleen Lonsdale Building, the Wellcome Collection hosts a series of rotating exhibitions focused on science, medicine, life, and art. Apparently there‚Äôs a lovely library open to everyone too!
